importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article is updated to reflect the current status of the federal government shutdown on Day 21, with potential extension into early November.
This is the open enrollment deadline for Obamacare health plans; if the subsidies lapse, premiums could double, which may pressure Democrats to end the shutdown to avoid political backlash.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has lasted 21 days and could extend beyond the current record, reaching 35 days if unresolved. This timeline is critical for assessing political and policy consequences.

keyTakeAways: The blame game in the shutdown is currently tilted toward Democrats, despite Republicans making the policy demand for extended Obamacare subsidies.
Public opinion polls consistently show Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats, especially in recent weeks, with a gap of up to 17 points in favor of blaming Republicans.
The demand for extended Obamacare subsidies is popular — 72% of Americans and 51% of Republicans support it, making it a politically viable leverage point.
Democrats may have a stronger political incentive to hold out, especially as the shutdown's impact on health care costs (premiums doubling) looms over open enrollment on November 1.
If Republicans fear the political fallout from premium hikes, they may be pressured to negotiate — suggesting a shift in the power dynamic from previous shutdowns.
Historically, the party making the policy demand (e.g., GOP in 1995–96 and 2018–19) lost politically and gave in; now, Democrats, despite being in the minority, are holding firm on a popular demand.
This shutdown presents a rare opportunity for Democrats to win politically by maintaining pressure and demonstrating resolve, even in a polarized environment.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Blake
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides the analysis on the political dynamics and public sentiment surrounding the shutdown, highlighting shifts in blame allocation and public polling.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is central to the political narrative, claiming Democrats are losing in the polls and accusing them of causing the shutdown, despite public polling showing otherwise.

namedEntities.name: Marjorie Taylor Greene
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is cited as warning Republicans that they may be pressured to negotiate due to fear of premium hikes from subsidy cuts.

namedEntities.name: Reuters-Ipsos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Conducted a poll showing Americans blame Republicans more than Democrats, indicating a shift in public perception of blame.

namedEntities.name: CNBC
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Conducted a poll showing a large majority of Americans blame Trump and Republicans over Democrats, reinforcing the current blame game.

namedEntities.name: KFF
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided data showing that health insurance premiums could double in most cases if subsidies lapse, which is a key policy consequence.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central policy demand in the shutdown — extending subsidies — is tied to public support and potential cost impacts on individuals.

namedEntities.name: Republican Party
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are demanding policy changes (border wall) and are blamed more by the public for the shutdown, despite having made the initial policy demand.

namedEntities.name: Democratic Party
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are demanding extended subsidies, which are popular, and are currently winning the blame game despite making no policy demand — a reversal of historical trends.

namedEntities.name: 1995–1996 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a precedent where Republicans lost politically due to public blame, showing how blame shifts affect political outcomes.

namedEntities.name: 2018–2019 shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Another precedent where Republicans lost politically due to public blame and policy failure; used to contrast the current situation where Democrats appear to be winning the blame game.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The federal government shutdown has reached 21 days, with the potential to exceed the previous record of 35 days. Unlike past shutdowns where the party making the policy demand (Republicans in 1995–96 and 2018–19) lost politically and gave in, the current situation is reversed: Democrats are demanding extended Obamacare subsidies, which are widely supported (72% of Americans), and are now winning the public blame game. Polls show Americans blame Republicans more than Democrats, with a gap of up to 17 points. This dynamic is especially significant because the policy demand is popular and politically viable. As the deadline for open enrollment approaches on November 1, the financial impact of subsidy cuts — including doubled health insurance premiums — may pressure Republicans to negotiate. Democrats may therefore have a rare opportunity to win politically by maintaining pressure, even though they are not making the initial policy demand. The article raises questions about whether Democrats will hold out or concede, depending on how Republicans respond to the potential political consequences of premium hikes and the public’s perception of blame.
title: Could Democrats win the shutdown standoff? They’re still winning the blame game
